title: Malmesbury Abbey and River Walk Route

images.title: Philip Halling / Malmesbury and the River Avon
images.caption: Malmesbury and the River Avon. Both the Abbey and St Paul's steeple can be seen on the skyline, the Sherston Branch of the River Avon is in the foreground.

images.title: Howard Morland / St John's Bridge over River Avon (Sherston branch) at Malmesbury
images.caption: St John's Bridge over River Avon (Sherston branch) at Malmesbury

images.title: Brian Robert Marshall / The Old Bell Inn from Malmesbury Abbey
images.caption: The Old Bell Inn from Malmesbury Abbey. The viewpoint is just in front of the south porch of the 12th century abbey. The abbey has had its ups and down but was restored about 100 years ago. The Old Bell is a relatively recent building dating to the early 13th century.

images.title: Brian Robert Marshall / Topiary, Abbey House Gardens, Malmesbury
images.caption: Topiary, Abbey House Gardens. The garden is owned by its creators, Ian and Barbara Pollard. It is well worth a visit if you're of a horticultural turn of mind.

images.title: Philip Halling / Malmesbury Abbey
images.caption: The present abbey dates from the 12th century, and was consecrated about 1180, however, previously a monastery was established on the site around 676 by Aldhelm.

images.title: Colin Smith / Malmesbury Cross.
images.caption: The 16th Century Market Cross stands at the T-junction in the town centre. The spire belongs to the Abbey.

images.title: Philip Halling / Tower House, Malmesbury
images.caption: Tower House. The Tower House is a private dwelling, however it once served as a coaching inn. The tower was built in 1834 as an observatory.

description: A circular walk around the Wiltshire town of Malmesbury visiting the historic abbey and the River Avon. It's a very attractive town with numerous historic buildings, a photogenic market cross and picturesque river scenes to enjoy. The walk starts at the 12th century abbey which has a history stretching back to the 7th century. It's one of the premium attractions in the county with stunning architecture and a fascinating history. You can also visit the Abbey House Gardens which cover 5 acres and have some fine topiary. Head north past the Cloister Gardens and you will soon come to the Tetbury Branch of the River Avon. You can follow a series of nice riverside paths around the town before returning to the centre. Here you will pass the noteworthy Malmesbury Market Cross. The cross was built in the 15th century possibly using stone salvaged from the recently ruined part of the abbey. There's also a number of 16th-century almshouses and the medieval Tower House. It contains a high-roofed main hall where it is said Henry VIII dined after hunting in nearby Bradon Forest.
